resources.text: Type erasure is a property of Java generics. It means that the generic objects inside the generic class are treated as an Object (or, when an upper bound is present, they're treated as that bound - see below).
resources.code:
public class Calculator<T> {

    private T currentValue;
    
    public Calculator(T startingValue) {
         currentValue = startingValue;
    }
    
    public T add(T number) {
         /*
         How to add the parameter to the current value?!
         Only Object methods are available, for example:
         toString(), hashCode()
          */
         return currentValue;
    }
    
    public T subtract(T number) {
         //how to subtract the parameter from the current value?!
         return currentValue;
    }
}
resources.text: In this simple Calculator class we store a value and want to be able add and subtract other values from it. However, with our current generics knowledge, this does not seem possible:
resources.code:
//Fine, but we still can't add the doubles inside the class!
Calculator<Double> calc = new Calculator<>(0.0);

//This makes no sense, but it's still allowed.
Calculator<Boolean> boolCalc = new Calculator<>(false);
resources.text: We need a way to be able to do addition/subtraction (if it is possible, like with the first calculator) and to disallow the creation of invalid objects, such as the boolean calculator.
Bounding the generic types is the solution to the problems seen above.
resources.boxed: To create an upper bound, we need a base class (or interface). Only the children of this base class will be allowed, thus the base class will be called an upper bound of the possible types (the base class is "above" the possible types in the class hierarchy).
resources.text: When there is an upper bound on a type parameter, objects of this type will be treated as the base class, and not as Object (in other words, type erasure will not reduce to Object, but to the base class).
resources.boxed: So all we need is a base class for the Calculator. Luckily there is a common base class for numeric types, java.lang.Number.
resources.text: Number has a useful method, doubleValue which returns a primitive double, the actual value of the numeric variable as a real number:
resources.code:
//Integer and Double extends Number
Integer intNum = 1;
Double doubleNum = 3.2;

System.out.println(intNum.doubleValue()); //1.0
System.out.println(doubleNum.doubleValue()); //3.2
resources.text: The only thing left is to learn how to write an upper bound. The extends keyword is used, to indicate that the generic type must be a subclass of the upper bound:
resources.code:
public class Calculator<T extends Number> {

    private double currentValue;
    
    public Calculator(T startingValue) {
         currentValue = startingValue.doubleValue();
    }
    
    public double add(T number) {
         //we have access to Number methods too, not only Object methods!
         currentValue += number.doubleValue();
         return currentValue;
    }
    
    public double subtract(T number) {
         //we have access to Number methods too, not only Object methods!
         currentValue += number.doubleValue();
         return currentValue;
    }

    public double getValue() {
         return currentValue;
    }
}
resources.text: You may have noticed that the change from T to double in some places. Java generics is not that powerful, and you'll undoubtedly come across limitations which will force you to make code a bit less generic to make it work.
resources.advanced:
Why could the return value not stay T? Because then we'd have to cast from double to T, and that would fail for any T that isn't Double.

Ok, so make currentValue also T, you might say. But then we could not add or subtract values from that (because Number has only getters, but no setters, and it's abstract)!
resources.text: Despite these small setbacks, the calculator now supports all numeric types. It'll return its result as doubles.
resources.code:
//For example, a float calculator
Calculator<Float> floatCalc = new Calculator<>(0.5f);
floatCalc.add(21.44f);
floatCalc.subtract(1.23f);
System.out.println("Final result: " + floatCalc.getValue());
resources.text: Another benefit is that now the compiler will reject invalid types:
resources.code:
//Compile time ERROR!
Calculator<Boolean> boolCalc = new Calculator<>(false);

interactive.instruction: Update the vector class from the previous chapter to use an upper bounded type parameter!
interactive.data:
class Vector<T ___ Number> {
    private T[] elements;
    public Vector(T[] elements) {
         this.elements = elements;
    }
    public double dotProduct(Vector<___> other) throws IllegalArgumentException {
         if(elements.length != other.elements.length) throw new IllegalArgumentException();
         double product = 0;
         for(int i=0; i<elements.length; i++) {
              product += elements[i].doubleValue() * other.elements[i].doubleValue();
         }
         return product;
    }
}

resources.text: Interfaces can also be used as an upper bound. In this case, only classes that implement the given interface will be allowed. Despite this, when declaring the bound, you must still use the extends keyword, not the implements keyword!
resources.code:
class MustCompare<T extends Comparable<T>> {
    
    //Comparing intensifies here...
    
}
resources.text: As you can see it's even possible to use the type parameter T to specify the upper bounds type arguments!

It's also allowed to have multiple upper bounds, but there are limitations: among the upper bounds, only one can be an actual class, the rest must be interfaces (this makes sense, since it's impossible to have multiple parent classes).
resources.code:
class PickyClass<T extends Thread & Serializable & Comparable<T>> {
    
    /*
    Do something with serializable and comparable
    background threads.
    */
    
}
resources.text: The & symbol must be used to list the upper bounds, and the class must be the first, the interfaces have to follow it.
